translated: Verses of the Elders 19.1
Verses of the Elders🔽The Collection of Elders’ Verses
The First Chapter
Tālapuṭa’s Verses🔽When will I live alone, without a companion,
in the mountain caves,
seeing all existence as impermanent,

original: Taṁ me idaṁ taṁ nu kadā bhavissati.
analyzed: tat me idam tam nu kadā bhavissati
translated: will that be for me?
When will I, a sage, with torn robes,
wearing a saffron robe, without possessions, without hope,

analyzed: rāgan ca dosan ca tathā iva moha
translated: having destroyed passion, hatred, and delusion,
live happily in the wind?

analyzed: kadā aniccam vadha roga nīḍa  kāyam imam maccu jarāyu padduta
translated: When will I, contemplating this body,🔽impermanent, a nest of disease and death,
afflicted by death and old age,

original: Eko vane taṁ nu kadā bhavissati.
analyzed: ekaḥ vane tam nu kadā bhavissati
translated: live alone in the forest, without fear?

analyzed: kadā nuham bhaya jananim dukha āvaha  taṇhālatam
translated: When will I, taking up the sharp sword of wisdom,🔽cut down the craving vine, which produces fear and brings suffering,
which follows many courses,

analyzed: chetvā vase tam pi kadā bhavissati
translated: and live free?

analyzed: kadā nu paññā maya mugga teja
translated: When will I, having quickly taken up the weapon of wisdom,
the sword of the sages,

analyzed: mā aram sa senam sahasā bhañjissa
translated: quickly destroy Māra and his army,
and sit on the lion throne?
When will I be seen by all who gather,
By those who revere the Dhamma, the noble ones,
By those who see things as they really are, who have conquered the senses,
And be able to practice with them?

original: Kadā nu maṁ tandi khudā pipāsā,
translated: When will I not be hindered by laziness, hunger, thirst,

original: Vātātapā kīṭasarīsapā vā;🔽Na bādhayissanti na taṁ giribbaje,
analyzed: vāta ātapā kīṭa sarīsapā vā  na bādhayissanti na tam giribbaje
translated: Wind, sun, insects, reptiles,
In the mountain cave? When will that be?

original: Kadā nu kho yaṁ viditaṁ mahesinā,
analyzed: kadā nu khalu yam viditam mahā isinā
translated: When will I, with a concentrated mind, mindful,

analyzed: cattāri saccāni su duddasāni  samāhitattaḥ satimāḥ agaccha
translated: Approach the four truths, so hard to see,🔽Which have been known by the Great Seer?

original: Paññāya taṁ taṁ nu kadā bhavissati.
analyzed: paññāya tam tam nu kadā bhavissati
translated: When will that be through wisdom?

original: Kadā nu rūpe amite ca sadde,
analyzed: kadā nu rūpe amite ca sadde
translated: When will I, with regard to forms, sounds,
Smells, tastes, and tactile objects,
Be restrained by the fire of peace?

original: Paññāya dacchaṁ tadidaṁ kadā me.🔽Kadā nuhaṁ dubbacanena vutto,
analyzed: paññāya daccham tat idam kadā me  kadā nuham dubbacanena vuttaḥ
translated: When will I see that?

original: Tato nimittaṁ vimano na hessaṁ;🔽Atho pasatthopi tato nimittaṁ,🔽Tuṭṭho na hessaṁ tadidaṁ kadā me.
analyzed: tatas nimittam vimanaḥ na  atho pasatthaḥ pi  tuṭṭhaḥ na hessam tat idam kadā me
translated: When will I not be displeased by the words of the difficult to tame,🔽Or delighted by praise? When will that be?

original: Kadā nu kaṭṭhe ca tiṇe latā ca,
analyzed: kadā nu kaṭṭhe ca tiṇe latā ca
translated: When will I be free from the thought of wood, grass, and vines,
These aggregates and these other things,
Both internal and external,

original: Samaṁ tuleyyaṁ tadidaṁ kadā me.🔽Kadā nu maṁ pāvusakālamegho,
analyzed: samam tuleyyam tat idam kadā me  kadā nu mama pāvusa kāla meghaḥ
translated: When will I weigh them equally?🔽When will the rain cloud of the right time
With fresh water in the forest,
Pour down on me who is walking on the path of asceticism?

original: Ovassate taṁ nu kadā bhavissati.🔽Kadā mayūrassa sikhaṇḍino vane,
analyzed: ovassate tam nu kadā bhavissati  kadā mayūrassa sikhaṇḍinaḥ vane
translated: When will that happen?🔽When will I hear in the forest
The cry of the peacock with a crest on its head,
And rise up for the attainment of the deathless?
When will that be thought of?

analyzed: kadā nu gaṅgam yamunam saraḥ sati
translated: When will I, without hesitation, cross🔽The Ganges, Yamunā, Sārasvatī,

analyzed: pātālakhittam vaḷavāmukham ca  a sajjamānaḥ patareyyam iddhiyā
translated: Pātālakhittā, and the Vāḷavāmukha by psychic power?
When will that frightening thing happen?

original: Kadā nu nāgova asaṅgacārī,🔽Padālaye kāmaguṇesu chandaṁ;
analyzed: kadā nu nāgā uva asaṅga cārī  pada ālaye kāmaguṇesu chanda
translated: When will I, like an elephant without attachment,🔽Destroy desire for the qualities of sensual pleasure,
And, having renounced all beautiful signs,

original: Jhāne yuto taṁ nu kadā bhavissati.
analyzed: jhāne yutaḥ tam nu kadā bhavissati
translated: Be devoted to jhāna? When will that be?
When will I, like a poor man in debt,
Having attained a treasure, oppressed by creditors,
I will be satisfied when I have attained the Teacher’s Dispensation,
When will that be, O Great Seer?
For many years I have been asked by you,

analyzed: agāra vāsena alam nu te idam
translated: ‘Is it enough for you to live in a house?’
Now that I have gone forth,
Why, O mind, do you not apply yourself?

analyzed: nanu aham citta tayā amhi yācitaḥ
translated: Have I not been asked by you, O mind,

analyzed: giribbaje citrachadā vihaṅgamā  mahinda ghosa tthanita abhigajjinaḥ
translated: ‘In the city of Giribbaja there are birds with variegated feathers’;
They will delight in you, O meditator in the forest,🔽Who will listen to the sound of Mahinda’s voice.

original: Kulamhi mitte ca piye ca ñātake,
analyzed: kulamhi mitte ca piye ca ñātake
translated: In the family, with dear friends and relatives,

analyzed: khiḍḍa aratim kāma guṇam ca loke
translated: With the delight of play and the pleasures of the world;
Having abandoned all this I have come here,

original: Athopi tvaṁ citta na mayha tussasi.
translated: And still, O mind, you are not satisfied with me.

original: Mameva etaṁ na hi tvaṁ paresaṁ,🔽Sannāhakāle paridevitena kiṁ;
analyzed: mama iva etam na hi tvam paresa  sannāha kāle paridevitena ki
translated: This is for me alone, not for others,🔽What is the use of lamenting at the time of buckling on the armour?
Looking on all this as unsteady,
I went forth seeking the state of deathlessness.
The one who speaks in connected series, the highest of bipeds,
The great physician, the charioteer of men to be tamed;
‘The mind is unsteady, like a monkey,
hard to resist for one not free from passion.
Sensual pleasures are varied, sweet, and charming,
where fools are deceived, who are ignorant.
They seek suffering, those who desire rebirth,
led by the mind, they are cast into hell.
‘Live in the forest resounding with peacocks and geese,
surrounded by leopards and tigers;
Abandon concern for the body, do not be disappointed,’
thus, mind, you urge me in the past.
‘Develop the jhānas and the spiritual powers,
the faculties, the powers, the factors of awakening and concentration;

analyzed: tissaḥ ca vijjā phusa buddha sāsane
translated: and the three knowledges, touch the Buddha’s Dispensation,’
thus, mind, you urge me in the past.
‘Develop the path for attaining the Deathless,🔽which leads out, the basis for the destruction of all suffering;
the eightfold path, which purifies all defilements,’
thus, mind, you urge me in the past.
‘Properly contemplate the five aggregates as suffering,

original: Yato ca dukkhaṁ samudeti taṁ jaha;
analyzed: yatas ca dukkham samudeti tam jaha
translated: and abandon that from which suffering originates;
right here make an end to suffering,’
thus, mind, you urge me in the past.
‘Impermanent, painful’ you saw them well,

analyzed: suññam anattā ati agham vadhanti ca
translated: ‘Empty, not-self’ you saw them as a danger.
You stopped the mind’s discursive thought,’
Thus, mind, you urged me on in the past.
‘Bald, ugly, a beggar with a bowl in hand,
You should go begging from families.
You should apply yourself to the Teacher’s words,’
Thus, mind, you urged me on in the past.
‘Well-restrained, walking between the hedges,
With a mind free from attachment to sensual pleasures in families,
Like the moon in the bright fortnight,’

original: Itissu maṁ citta pure niyuñjasi.🔽‘Āraññiko hohi ca piṇḍapātiko,
analyzed: itissu mam citta pure niyuñjasi  āraññikaḥ ca piṇḍapātikaḥ
translated: Thus, mind, you urged me on in the past.🔽‘Be a forest-dweller, an alms-goer,
A charnel-ground dweller, a rag-robe wearer,
A non-dipper, always delighting in the ascetic practices,’

original: Itissu maṁ citta pure niyuñjasi.🔽Ropetva rukkhāni yathā phalesī,
analyzed: itissu mam citta pure niyuñjasi  ropetvā rukkhāni yathā phalesī
translated: Thus, mind, you urged me on in the past.

analyzed: mūle tarum chettu tam eva icchasi
translated: Just as, having planted trees, you want to cut down the very tree at the root,
So you act like that, mind,
In that you urge me on, who am impermanent, unstable.
Formless, far-ranging, solitary wanderer,

analyzed: na te karissam vacanam idān iha
translated: I will not do your bidding now.

analyzed: dukkhā hi kāmā kaṭukā mahat bhayā
translated: For sensual pleasures are painful, bitter, much to be feared,

analyzed: nibbānam eva abhimanaḥ carissa  na aham alakkhyā ahirikkatāya vā
translated: I will go forth to Nibbāna.🔽Not because of lack of shame or lack of conscience,

analyzed: na citta hetū na ca dūra kantanā
translated: Not for the sake of wealth or for the sake of a wife,

analyzed: ājīva hetū ca aham na nikkhami
translated: Not for the sake of livelihood did I go forth,

original: Kato ca te citta paṭissavo mayā.
analyzed: kataḥ ca te citta paṭissavaḥ mayā
translated: I have given you my reply, mind.
‘Fewness of wishes is praised by the Noble Ones,
The abandoning of conceit is the stilling of suffering’;
Thus, mind, you urged me then,
But now you go your former way.

original: Taṇhā avijjā ca piyāpiyañca,🔽Subhāni rūpāni sukhā ca vedanā;
analyzed: taṇhā avijjā ca piya apiyam ca  subhāni rūpāni sukhā ca vedanā
translated: Craving, ignorance, and the pleasant and painful,🔽Beautiful forms, and pleasant feelings,
The agreeable qualities of sensual pleasures are vomited up,
I cannot bear to vomit them up.

original: Sabbattha te citta vaco kataṁ mayā,
analyzed: sabbattha te citta vaco katam mayā
translated: I have done your bidding, mind, in every way,
For many births you were not angered by me;
You were born within me through gratitude,

analyzed: dukkhe ciram sa saritam tayā kate
translated: You have made me wander long in suffering.

analyzed: tvañc eva naḥ citta karosi brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: You alone, mind, make me a brahmin,
You make me a noble, a king’s man,

original: Vessā ca suddā ca bhavāma ekadā,
analyzed: vessā ca suddā ca bhavāmaḥ ekadā
translated: Sometimes we are Vessas, sometimes Suddas,

original: Devattanaṁ vāpi taveva vāhasā.🔽Taveva hetū asurā bhavāmase,
analyzed: devattanam vā api tava iva vāhasā  tava iva hetū asurāḥ bhavāmase
translated: Or even gods, through your own power.🔽Through you we become Asuras,
Through you we become hell-beings,
And sometimes we are animals,
Or even ghosts, through your own power.

original: Nanu dubbhissasi maṁ punappunaṁ,🔽Muhuṁ muhuṁ cāraṇikaṁva dassayaṁ;
analyzed: nanu mama punar puna  muhum muhum dassaya
translated: Will you not be ashamed again and again,🔽Showing yourself again and again like a vagabond?
You are tempting me as if I were a madman,

analyzed: kiñca api te citta virādhitam mayā
translated: Though I have displeased you, O mind.
This mind formerly roamed about
As it liked, as it wished, as it pleased;
But now I will restrain it wisely,
As a mahout controls an elephant with a goad.

analyzed: satthā ca me lokam imam adhiṭṭhahi
translated: The Teacher has established this world
As impermanent, unstable, and without substance;
Turn to the Victor’s Dispensation, O mind,

original: Tārehi oghā mahatā suduttarā.🔽Na te idaṁ citta yathā purāṇakaṁ,
analyzed: tārehi oghā mahatā su duttarā  na te idam citta yathā purāṇaka
translated: And deliver me across the great flood.🔽This is not the same as before, O mind;
I am not able to return to your control.
I have gone forth in the Dispensation of the Great Seer;
Not those like me who are bent on destruction.
Mountains, oceans, rivers, and the earth,
The four directions, the intermediate directions, below and above;
All are impermanent, the three worlds are oppressed,
Where have you gone, mind, to enjoy happiness?
What more can you do to me, mind, you who are so persistent?
You are not fit to be a follower of mine, mind;
I will never kiss the mouth of a two-faced flatterer,
Shame on a full vessel with nine holes leaking.
Frequented by wild boars and deer,
On a beautiful rocky cliff, as if carved;
In a forest grove with fresh water and ripe fruits,

analyzed: tahim guhā geha gataḥ ramissasi  su nīla gīvā su sikhā su pekhunā
translated: There, in a cave-house, you will enjoy yourself.🔽With their beautiful necks, beautiful crests, and beautiful eyes,
The birds with their beautiful leaf-like feathers;
Calling out with their very sweet voices,
They will delight you, meditator, in the forest.
When the rain falls and the grass is four fingers high,
In the flowering forest, like a cloud;

analyzed: na ga antare viṭapi samaḥ sayissa
translated: I will lie down in the middle of the forest, like a rock,
That soft bed of mine, like cotton.

analyzed: tathā tu kassāmi yathā api issaro
translated: I’ll work as if I were the master,

original: Yaṁ labbhati tenapi hotu me alaṁ;
analyzed: yam labbhati tena api hotu me ala
translated: and whatever I get will be enough for me.

analyzed: na tāham kassāmi yathā a tanditaḥ
translated: I won’t work as if I were lazy,
like a cat in a mouse-hole.

analyzed: tathā tu kassāmi yathā api issaro
translated: I’ll work as if I were the master,

original: Yaṁ labbhati tenapi hotu me alaṁ;
analyzed: yam labbhati tena api hotu me ala
translated: and whatever I get will be enough for me.

original: Viriyena taṁ mayha vasānayissaṁ,🔽Gajaṁva mattaṁ kusalaṅkusaggaho.
analyzed: viriyena tam mayha vasa ānayissa  mattam
translated: I’ll control you with energy,🔽like a skilled elephant trainer controls an elephant.
For it’s through you, well-controlled and straight,
like a horse by a charioteer,
that I can follow the auspicious path
always frequented by those who protect the mind.
I’ll bind you firmly to the object,
like an elephant to a firm post with a rope.

analyzed: tam me su guttam satiyā su bhāvita
translated: Well-guarded by me, well-developed with mindfulness,
you’ll go free from attachment to all kinds of existence.
Having cut you loose with wisdom from the wrong path,
and having directed you onto the right path with effort,
having seen the origin, the ending, and the arising and passing away,
you’ll be the heir of the foremost speaker.
Having resolved the four reversals,
You have led me around like a village cow;
Have you not served the Great Sage, the Compassionate One,
Who has cut the bonds and fetters?
Like a deer in a beautiful forest,
You have enjoyed the delightful mountain, adorned with rain clouds;
There, on that mountain, I will play,

original: Asaṁsayaṁ citta parā bhavissasi.🔽Ye tuyha chandena vasena vattino,
analyzed: a sa sayam citta parā bhavissasi  ye tuyha chandena vasena vattino
translated: Without a doubt, mind, you will be defeated.🔽Those men and women who live according to your will,

original: Narā ca nārī ca anubhonti yaṁ sukhaṁ;
analyzed: narā ca nārī ca anubhonti yam sukha
translated: And experience happiness,
Not knowing, under the control of Māra,
Your disciples delight in existence, mind.”
… The Elder Tālapuṭa …
The Chapter on Wisdom is finished.
The summary:
In the Chapter on Wisdom,
There is one pure Tālapuṭa;
There are fifty verses there,
And another five.
